Section 156(d) of title 35, United States Code, is amended to allow for an interim extension of a patent term if the regulatory review period may extend beyond the patent expiration. The owner or agent can submit an application for extension 6 months to 30 days before the term expires. The application must include the product subject to regulatory review. The application for interim patent extension must include the product under regulatory review, patent identity, claims related to the product, activities undertaken during the review period, and any additional information required by the Commissioner. The Commissioner may require patent information. If a patent is eligible for extension, a notice will be published, and an interim extension certificate may be issued for up to 1 year. The patent owner can apply for up to 4 subsequent interim extensions. Each application must be submitted before the expiration of the previous extension. Each certificate of interim extension shall be recorded in the patent file and considered part of the original patent. Any interim extension granted will end 60 days after product commercial marketing permission, but can be further extended up to 5 years. Rights from extended patents during interim extension period are protected. During interim extension, patents are limited to uses or methods under regulatory review, protecting rights for up to 5 years after product commercial marketing permission. SEC. 2. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Amendments are made to Section 156 of title 35, United States Code, including changes to subsections (a), (b), and (e) to clarify rights and references within the section.
